Richard Manning Karp

Biography

Born in Boston, Massachusetts in 1935, Richard Manning Karp he was the oldest of four siblings. Both of his parents were graduates and both of them at Harvard, his father wanted to be a doctor but had to change his plan because of the high fees that the school required. His mother got her degree at the age of 57 after taking some evening courses. He, like his parents before, attended Harvard University as well, where in 1955 he got his bachelor degree, in 1956 he got his master degree and finally in 1959 he got his Ph.d in applied mathematics. He then went working at IBM for a while, then in 1968 he bacame professor at the "University of California, Berkeley" during this period the won the Turing Award for his reseach explanied in the next section.

Research

Citing the official presentation of this award:
"For his continuing contributions to the theory of algorithms including the development of efficient algorithms for network flow and other combinatorial optimization problems, the identification of polynomial-time computability with the intuitive notion of algorithmic efficiency, and, most notably, contributions to the theory of NP-completeness. Karp introduced the now standard methodology for proving problems to be NP-complete which has led to the identification of many theoretical and practical problems as being computationally difficult."

After contributing a lot in the field of algorithms he completely changed subject, moving into the field of Computational Biology. Karp first examined physical mapping of genes, devising algorithms to help determine the physical location of genes in a genome given the limited indirect experimental information about gene location. Such algorithms were incredibly important before affordable full DNA sequencing became available.

Turing Award 1985
Other Important Contribution
1971 Edmonds-Karp algorithm
1973 Hopcroft-Karp algorithm
1980 Karp-Lipton theorem
1987 Rabin-Karp string search algorithm

In memory of A.M. Turing
